RISK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM
(Executive Summary and Data Elements)

This document and the accompanying spreadsheet contain all required information in 
order to meet 40 CFR 68 Risk Management Program including an Executive Summary 
and RMP data elements (68.155 through 68.185).

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1.0 Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The Kraft Foods Global, Inc. facility in Springfield, Missouri has an excellent record in preventing and 
minimizing releases of anhydrous* ammonia. This facility has a thorough emergency 
training program for on-site emergency responders.  This facility has implemented the 
SAP electronic preventive maintenance system that uses a real time database to track 
training and inspection dates and issue reminders to responsible groups.

The emergency response policies at this facility ensure that there is emergency response 
coverage, 24 hours - 7 days per week.  There are also adequate provisions for 
coordination with outside agencies, such as with the Springfield Fire Department in the 
event of an emergency. 

*From this point in the Executive Summ

ary, anhydrous ammonia will be synonymous with 
ammonia.

2.0 Process Description and Regulated Substances

At this location Kraft Foods Global, Inc. manufactures and processes dairy products.  The SIC code 
for the primary process at this facility is 2023.  This facility is capable of producing various 
dairy products including cheese for consumer intake.  Many areas of the plant are 
refrigerated to preserve the dairy products. Some of these areas include coolers, chillers, 
storage tanks and some processes.  The plant also produces some pasta products. 

Kraft Foods Global, Inc. has one regulated substance under 40 CFR 68, anhydrous ammonia, at this 
location.  Ammonia is used as a cooling agent for the refrigeration of the food products in 
the various areas described above.

The ammonia threshold for triggering applicability to 40 CFR 68 is 10,000 pounds. The 
quantity of ammonia stored on-site is approximately 141,247 pounds. Thus, 40 CFR 68 is 
applicable to Kraft Foods Global, Inc. in Springfield, MO.

 3.0 General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific 
Prevention Steps

This facility has developed an OSHA PSM program for their ammonia refrigeration 
system.  Ammonia falls under the RMP Program 3 prevention program, which is identical 
to the OSHA PSM program.  EPA has stated that if the process is in compliance with 
OSHA PSM, it is in compliance with RMP Program 3.  Thus, Kraft's ammonia PSM has 
been reviewed and determined to be complete for the RMP document. 

There are several aspects of the prevention program that are key:

1.The Utility Service Area design (USA) serves as an excellent safeguard for 
plant personnel because it greatly reduces the amount of ammonia piping 
inside occupied rooms.  Since most of the pipe work is out of the way of 
people and the machinery and so there is less of a chance of an ammonia 
release.

2.The plant maintains good training, certification and employee awareness of 
operating procedures. 

3.A

n electronic control monitoring system and emergency shut down system is in place for the 
entire engine room process.  

4.0 Five-year Accident History

The review of this facility's accident history includes the following range of dates: May 25, 1999 - May 25, 2004.  There have been no releases at this facility as defined in 40 CFR 
Part 68.42(a).


5.0 Emergency Response Program 

As mentioned earlier, this facility has developed an emergency response in which plant 
employees are divided into various management and response teams.  There are nine in-
plant contacts for an emergency, a list of these contacts can be found in the Emergency 
Response Plan (SPCC).  There are also back-up personnel in the event that the primary incident 
response personnel cannot be contacted.  The emergency response plan includes 
information about the frequency of employee emergency response training, as well as a 
detailed description of the training content.  There are also specific procedures to follow in 
the event of a fire and ammonia emergency.  Response team members participate in a 
mock spill cleanup annually.  All trained ER team members have pagers/phones 
that can be activated.    

At the discretion of the Incident Commander, the Springfield Fire Department will be 
called to provide emergency responders and equipment.  The Springfield Fire Department 
will also be called for all fire related emergencies.  In all cases where an ambulance is 
called, the fire department is also called to the scene. 


6.0 Planned Changes to Improve Safety -

Based on the PHA completed for ammonia, a list of action items was developed and is 
being monitored to determine if implementation was accomplished. The What-If method 
is used for each component of the ammonia system.  There are numerous examples of 
safety improvements as a result of the PSA results.  These improvements include:

Recommendation #1:  Install a post to protect the gauge glass on the high-pressure ammonia receiver

(ref. Q1).
Analysis: The area around the ammonia receiver and condensers routinely has fork truck traffic en route to the back ammonia compressor room dock.  Consequently, all ammonia system components in this area are at risk of damage resulting in an ammonia release.
Corrective action: A chain link fence was installed around the perimeter of the ammonia receiver and condenser area.  No vehicle traffic of any kind is permitted and the area was secured with a ¿one-way¿ turnstile gate.  This was completed in January of 2002.


Recommendation #2:  Install quick connect valves on all ammonia compressor thermosyphon heat exchangers to expedite system pump down in the event of an ammonia release from a flange (ref. Q4).
Analysis: A ¿quick connection¿ type valve is not designed to be a safe application for extremely hazardous materials such as ammonia refrigerant.  The thermosyphon heat exchangers are equipped with accessible isolation valves and evacuation valves with a screwed and capped outlet connection.
Corrective action:  None

Recommendation #3:  Discontinue purchasing/installing inferior ¿aftermarket¿ mechanical seals for ammonia screw compressors to reduce the frequency of seal failure and subsequent ammonia release (ref. Q5).
 Analysis:  Purchase history of mechanical seals supports recommendation.
Corrective action: Purchase all ammonia screw compressor mechanical seals from OEM (FES) supplier effective in July of 2000 (exact date unknown).

Recommendation #4:  Install a lock on ammonia receiver ¿fill¿ valve so that Ammonia Operator on duty can inspect bulk vendor equipment prior to unloading (ref. Q7).
Analysis:  An excellent recommendation, both for the reason stated as well as for security of the ammonia system.
Corrective action:  A lock was installed on the ammonia receiver ¿fill¿ valve in July of 2000 (exact date unknown).

Recommendation #5:  Install explosion proof lights, new exhaust fan, and hook existing alarms to Cantley (CAMS) system (ref. Q8).
An

alysis; Question # 8 regarded an ammonia release resulting from a 60¿ seal failure on the chill roll.  The surge room would not be involved in this scenario; however, question # 11 could apply to this recommendation.  Exhaust fan was checked and found to have ¿loose¿ belts.  The existing alarm system is audible and the area is normally occupied.  The existing alarm system also automatically starts the exhaust system when an ammonia level of 75ppm is reached. The installation of ammonia detectors (connected to the central control system) in all cooler/chiller areas is preferable but not critical to ammonia safety of the plant refrigeration system as these areas are typically staffed staffed 6/7 days/week and 24 hours/day.  
Corrective action: 1. Tighten belts on New Slice exhaust fan.  2. Future ammonia system (new construction projects and major repairs) will include ammonia detectors connected to the central control system. 

Recommendation #6:  Hook up New Slice surge drum liquid level alarms to Cantley system and interlock the refrigeration system with the product pump (ref. Q9).
Analysis: The scenario questioned (Q9) would not result in an ¿unsafe¿ condition.
Corrective action:  None

Recommendation #7:  This recommendation is identical to recommendation #6 and applies to Old Slice surge drums (ref. Q9).
Analysis:  Same as analysis #6.
Corrective action: None

Recommendation #8:  Same as recommendation #5 (ref. Q11).
Analysis:  Same as exhaust fan analysis #5.
Corrective action: Tighten belts on New Slice Surge Room.

Recommendation #9:  Install a new exhaust fan in Old Slice surge room (ref. Q14).
Analysis: Good recommendation.
Corrective action:  New fan purchased and installed in August 2000 (exact date unknown). 

Recommendation #10:  Install an ammonia detector inside Tri-Tray product cooler and connect to Cantley control system (ref. Q24).
Analysis: The installation of ammonia detectors (connected to the central control system) in all cooler/chiller areas

is preferable but not critical to ammonia safety of the plant refrigeration system as these areas are typically staffed 6/7 days/week and 24 hours/day.  
The eventual installation of ammonia detectors (connected to the central control system) in all cooler/chiller areas is preferable and would provide early warning when personnel are not in the area.  
Corrective action:  Future ammonia system (new construction projects and major repairs) will include ammonia detectors connected to the central control system. 


Recommendation #11:  Develop a preventive Maintenance work order to maintain mechanical integrity of 45lb cooling tunnel exhaust fan (ref. Q19).
Analysis:  Good recommendation.
Corrective action: Annual SAP PM work order #SPFCO54 developed and implemented.

Recommendation #12:  Install an ammonia detector in the 45lb refrigeration equipment room (ref. Q20).
Analysis: The installation of ammonia detectors (connected to the central control system) in all cooler/chiller areas is preferable but not critical to ammonia safety of the plant refrigeration system as these areas are typically staffed 6/7 days/week and 24 hours/day.  
The eventual installation of ammonia detectors (connected to the central control system) in all cooler/chiller areas is preferable and would provide early warning when personnel are not in the area.  
Corrective action:  Future ammonia system (new construction projects and major repairs) will include ammonia detectors connected to the central control system. 

Recommendation # 13:  Have a 2nd person establish proper valve position prior to evaporator ¿start-up¿. (ref. Q21).
Analysis:  The PSM ¿Standard Operating Procedures¿ (SOP) indentifys proper valve position for ¿normal¿ operation of all ammonia system equipment.  The Ammonia system Operators and Mechanics have received certification training on all SOPs and are competent to establish/verify valve position prior to starting up any ammonia equipment.
Corrective action:  None

Recommend

ation #14:  Replace Link line chiller and controls (ref. Q23)
Analysis:  The recommendation to replace the chiller was a text error ¿ the team intended it to read ¿Replace Link line chiller controls¿.  This was a good recommendation and plans had already been made to remove both the link and glass line chillers as part of a new process installation.
Corrective action:  The Link and Glass line chillers and controls were removed from service in November of 2002.

Recommendation #15:  Install an ammonia detector in the Cream Cheese cooler and connect to the Cantley system (CAMS) (ref. Q24).
Analysis: The installation of ammonia detectors (connected to the central control system) in all cooler/chiller areas is preferable but not critical to ammonia safety of the plant refrigeration system as these areas are typically staffed 6/7 days/week and 24 hours/day.  
The eventual installation of ammonia detectors (connected to the central control system) in all cooler/chiller areas is preferable and would provide early warning when personnel are not in the area.  
Corrective action:  Future ammonia system (new construction projects and major repairs) will include ammonia detectors connected to the central control system. 

Recommendation #16:  Install catwalks around milk tanks to access refrigeration controls (ref. Q28).
Analysis:  Catwalks would provide safer access to relief valve switching stations.
Corrective action: Preliminary engineering funding was requested and granted in 2002 for the 2003 budget.  Structural engineering was completed in 2003 and funding for platform installation was requested and granted 2003 for the 2004 budget.  PEM CAR was submitted for final approval in March of 2004.  Installation is planned for July/August of 2004.

Recommendation #17:  Check all milk tanks to verify that they are equipped with reseating relief valves to suction and that relief vent pipes are located where they will not discharge over relief switching valve (ref. Q29).
Analysis:

Kraft ammonia piping specifications do not require reseating relief valves back to suction; however, reseating relief valves will minimize the amount of ammonia released to the atmosphere when an ¿over pressure¿ condition occurs.
Corrective Action:  On new construction and major repairs, Kraft Springfield has standardized the practice of installing reseating relief valves back to suction.

Recommendations #18:  Install an ammonia detector in the Milk Receiving Tank Room and connect the alarm to the central control system (ref. Q30).
Analysis: The installation of ammonia detectors (connected to the central control system) in all cooler/chiller areas is preferable but not critical to ammonia safety of the plant refrigeration system as these areas are typically staffed 6/7 days/week and 24 hours/day.  
The eventual installation of ammonia detectors (connected to the central control system) in all cooler/chiller areas is preferable and would provide early warning when personnel are not in the area.  
Corrective action:  Future ammonia system (new construction projects and major repairs) will include ammonia detectors connected to the central control system. 

Recommendation #19, #20, and #21:  Install high-level ammonia liquid alarms, water temperature probes, and oil pots on facility ice builders (ref. Q32, Q33, Q34).
Analysis: The scenarios referenced in Questions 32, 33, and 34 do not represent any potential safety hazard.
Corrective action:  None
